rewritten.A: Great job! You found that Christians were brave because they "did not give up their faith" even when Romans hurt them. The story shows they kept believing no matter what happened.
rewritten.B: Good try! Constantine helped Christians later, but he didn't start the religion. The story says Jesus' followers were the first Christians who spread their beliefs.
rewritten.C: Nice thinking, but Christianity spread because brave people kept teaching about Jesus, not just because of miracles. Christians "did not give up" even when it was dangerous.
rewritten.D: Not quite! The story doesn't say Roman gods were stronger than Jesus. It shows Christians were brave because they kept believing even when Romans punished them.

original.A: You successfully identified key details to show that Christians were courageous. The text supports this when it says, “They put Christians in jail and killed many of them. But Christians did not give up their faith,” and describes Paul traveling to teach even though he was later killed. Remember to look for what people do during hard times and ask, “What does this show about their character?”
original.B: You may have focused on Constantine and thought he started Christianity, but the text says Jesus’ followers and Paul spread the religion, and later Constantine “stopped punishing Christians” and made it official. The lines “They put Christians in jail and killed many of them. But Christians did not give up their faith” show that Christians showed great courage. Next time, reread and check if your answer matches what happened before and after in the passage, not just one detail.
original.C: You may have focused on the miracles detail instead of the big idea. The passage says, “They put Christians in jail and killed many of them. But Christians did not give up their faith. They kept believing and teaching about Jesus,” which shows courage and keeping on teaching helped Christianity spread—not only miracles. The best choice is “Christians showed great courage in their beliefs”; next time, make sure your answer matches what the whole passage shows, not just one exciting part.
original.D: You may have thought Roman gods were stronger because the Romans ‘believed these gods kept their empire safe and strong,’ but the passage never compares their power to Jesus. Look at: ‘They put Christians in jail and killed many of them. But Christians did not give up their faith. They kept believing and teaching about Jesus’—this shows Christians showed great courage. Next time, stick to what the text says and find the lines that answer the question directly.

rewritten.A: You got it! The passage says Paul "helped spread Christianity more than anyone else." This shows the author thinks Paul's work was very important.

original.A: Correct! The author describes Paul as someone who 'helped spread Christianity more than anyone else' and explains how he traveled, taught, and started churches. This positive description shows the author values Paul's work. Use the author's word choices like 'helped spread' to identify their perspective.
original.B: Incorrect. The author never criticizes Paul's travels. Instead, the passage explains Paul 'traveled all around the Roman Empire, teaching people about Jesus' in a positive way. The author presents this as important work, not something wrong.
original.C: Incorrect. The author presents Paul's widespread travel as a strength, not a weakness. The passage says he 'started Christian churches in many cities,' showing his travels helped Christianity grow. Reread how the author describes Paul's actions.
original.D: Incorrect. While Constantine made Christianity official, the author specifically states Paul 'helped spread Christianity more than anyone else.' The author sees both as important but emphasizes Paul's unique role in spreading the faith. Notice the author's comparative language.

rewritten.D: Nice thinking, but the story never says Roman gods did miracles. It only talks about Jesus doing amazing things like miracles.

original.A: Correct! The author mentions miracles in the context of Jesus teaching and gathering followers, then explains 'Jesus had many followers who listened to his teachings.' By including miracles alongside teaching, the author shows they were part of what attracted people. Notice how authors connect details to show relationships.
original.B: Incorrect. The author mentions miracles but also discusses many other reasons Christianity grew: Jesus's teachings, Paul's travels, and Christians' persistence. The passage shows multiple factors, not just miracles. Reread the full passage to see all the reasons given.

original.D: Incorrect. The passage discusses Roman gods separately and never mentions them performing miracles. The author presents miracles as something specific to Jesus. Check where Roman gods are mentioned in the passage.

rewritten.A: You got it! The story explains why the Romans acted this way - they wanted to protect their beliefs. The author shows both sides of what happened.
rewritten.B: Good try! The story doesn't say the emperors were mean or unfair. It explains why they did what they did to protect their own beliefs.

rewritten.D: Nice thinking, but the emperors did understand religion! They had strong beliefs about their own Roman gods keeping them safe.

original.A: Correct! The author explains the emperors' reasoning: 'Romans believed these gods kept their empire safe and strong' and Christians 'thought it was wrong to worship Roman gods.' By explaining their perspective, the author shows understanding of why emperors acted this way, even without agreeing. This is how authors can present viewpoints neutrally.
original.B: Incorrect. While describing the persecution, the author also explains the emperors' reasoning about protecting Roman gods. The author presents both sides rather than calling emperors unfair. Look for how the author explains motivations, not just actions.
original.C: Incorrect. The author never suggests harsher punishment was needed. The passage describes persecution but doesn't advocate for it. The author presents events, not personal opinions about what should have happened. Distinguish between reporting and recommending.
original.D: Incorrect. The author explains the emperors had strong religious beliefs about Roman gods keeping the empire safe. This shows they understood religion's importance—they just had different beliefs than Christians. Reread the emperors' motivations in paragraph 4.

rewritten.A: Great job! The story shows Christianity reached "people close to the emperor" when his mother became Christian. This helped explain why Constantine accepted the religion too.

original.A: Correct! The author mentions Constantine's mother right before explaining Constantine himself became Christian and changed policies. This detail shows Christianity had spread even into the emperor's family, making the religion's acceptance more understandable. Authors include specific details to support their larger points.
original.B: Incorrect. The author mentions one woman (Constantine's mother) but also discusses many men including Jesus, Paul, and emperors. The passage doesn't compare religious participation by gender. One example doesn't prove a pattern.
original.C: Incorrect. The author mentions the mother as one factor but also notes 'there were many Christians in the empire' by then. The passage suggests multiple reasons, not just maternal influence. Look for all the reasons provided, not just one.
original.D: Incorrect. The passage doesn't discuss family religious patterns generally. This detail is specific to Constantine's family and Christianity's growth. Avoid overgeneralizing from specific examples in the text.

rewritten.A: Good try! The story doesn't compare Christianity to Roman beliefs much. It tells what happened in order: Jesus was born, then died, then his followers spread his message.

rewritten.D: Not quite! Christians refusing to worship Roman gods is just one detail. The whole story goes in time order from Jesus's birth to Christianity becoming Rome's religion.

original.A: You may have focused on a small compare-and-contrast detail (Romans worshiped many gods, Christians one God), but notice the time-order clues: “During the time when Emperor Augustus… Jesus was born,” “At first… Later… For many years… Everything changed with Emperor Constantine.” This shows the author explains Christianity’s growth by describing the sequence of events from Jesus’s birth to Constantine making it the official religion. original.B: You successfully identified the text’s structure (sequence) by noticing how the author shows Christianity growing step by step over time. original.C: You may have focused on the miracles detail, but notice how the passage goes in order: Jesus’s birth and teaching, his death, Paul spreading the faith, Romans punishing Christians, and then Constantine making it the empire’s religion. That means the author explains Christianity’s growth by putting events in order, not by listing miracles. Strategy: Check that your answer fits the whole passage, and look for clue words like “At first,” “Later,” and “Everything changed.”
original.D: You may have focused on the detail about Christians refusing to worship Roman gods, but that is just one small part. Look at the time order in the text: “Jesus was born,” “Pilate…,” “Paul traveled…,” “For many years…,” and “Everything changed with Emperor Constantine”—the author tells what happened step by step. To find the right answer, think about what the whole passage is doing and look for time-order clues; here it is describing the sequence of events in Christianity’s growth.

rewritten.A: Great job! The story tells events in time order: "During the time when Emperor Augustus ruled Rome" Jesus was born, then he died, then Christianity spread. It follows what happened first, next, and last.
rewritten.B: Good try! The story mentions Jesus, Paul, and Constantine, but it doesn't compare them. It tells about them in the order they lived in history.

rewritten.D: Nice thinking, but the story doesn't organize by different places. It organizes by time, showing events from Jesus's birth to much later in history.

original.A: Correct! The passage follows a chronological order: Jesus's birth during Augustus's rule, Jesus's death, Paul's missionary work, persecution under various emperors, and finally Constantine's acceptance 300 years later. This time sequence organizes the entire article. Look for organizational patterns like chronology to understand text structure.
original.B: Incorrect. While the passage mentions Jesus, Paul, and Constantine, it doesn't compare them directly. It presents them in time order as part of Christianity's historical development. The focus is on sequence, not comparison. Notice the difference between comparison and chronological presentation.
original.C: Incorrect. Although the passage mentions persecution (a problem) and Constantine's acceptance (a change), this isn't the overall organizing structure. The passage primarily follows time order, showing what happened first, next, and last. Identify the main organizing principle throughout the whole text.
original.D: Incorrect. The passage mentions cities and the Roman Empire generally but doesn't organize information by geographic regions. It follows time order instead, showing events from Jesus's time through Constantine's era. Check whether organization is based on place, time, or other principles.

rewritten.A: You got it! The story says Christians wouldn't worship Roman gods, and "this created a big problem." Then emperors treated them badly because of it.
rewritten.B: Good try! The story doesn't say Christians were stronger than Romans. It shows that not worshipping Roman gods made the emperors angry at Christians.

original.A: Correct! The passage explains Christians 'thought it was wrong to worship Roman gods' and then states 'This created a big problem for Christians' followed by 'Roman emperors treated Christians as enemies.' This shows a clear cause-and-effect connection. Authors use phrases like 'this created' to signal causal relationships.
original.B: Incorrect. The passage doesn't compare strength between groups. It explains a cause (refusing worship) and effect (persecution), not which group was stronger. The passage focuses on historical events, not strength comparisons. Distinguish between cause-effect and comparison.
original.C: Incorrect. The passage shows the refusal to worship came first ('Christians believed there was only one God'), then persecution followed ('Roman emperors treated Christians as enemies'). The text presents this in cause-effect order. Pay attention to the sequence of ideas presented.
original.D: Incorrect. The passage never discusses Roman gods losing power. It explains Christians' beliefs caused emperors to worry and persecute them. Focus on the relationships the author actually establishes between ideas, not unmentioned connections.

original.A: Correct! The passage states Paul was a Roman citizen, then immediately explains 'Paul traveled all around the Roman Empire.' Being a citizen gave Paul rights and freedom to move, which helped him spread Christianity. Authors mention details to explain how events were possible. Notice how details connect to what follows.
original.B: Incorrect. The author calls Paul important for spreading Christianity, not because of citizenship. The citizenship detail explains his ability to travel, not his importance level. Distinguish between details about status versus details about capabilities.
original.C: Incorrect. The passage explains Paul spread Christianity despite Roman beliefs, not that citizenship caused disagreement. Christians generally disagreed with Roman gods, not just Paul. This detail is about travel access, not beliefs. Check what idea the detail directly supports.
original.D: Incorrect. The passage doesn't explain how Paul became Christian. It mentions his citizenship then describes his missionary travels. The citizenship detail relates to his movement, not his conversion. Look at what information follows the detail for clues about its purpose.

original.A: Correct! Paragraph 5 begins with 'Everything changed' and contrasts the persecution period with Constantine's acceptance, ending with Christianity becoming the official religion. This structure emphasizes dramatic transformation. Look for words like 'everything changed' that signal structural shifts.
original.B: Incorrect. While the paragraph mentions previous persecution, it focuses on Constantine's specific actions and their results, not a detailed comparison between rulers. The structure emphasizes change over time, not point-by-point comparison. Notice the difference between describing change and comparing items.

original.D: Incorrect. The paragraph mentions Constantine and references earlier emperors generally but doesn't list multiple emperors. The structure focuses on Constantine's pivotal role, not cataloging rulers. Distinguish between focused explanation and comprehensive listing.

rewritten.A: You got it! The story says Constantine 'stopped punishing Christians' and made Christianity the official religion. He helped Christians instead of hurting them.

original.A: Correct! The passage states Constantine 'stopped punishing Christians' and 'Christianity became the official religion of the entire Roman Empire.' This shows he both ended persecution and actively supported Christianity. These are the key changes explicitly described in the text.
original.B: Incorrect. The passage says Christianity 'became the official religion' but never says Constantine forced everyone to convert immediately. Making something official is different from requiring conversion. Notice the difference between official status and forced conversion.

original.D: Incorrect. The passage doesn't mention Constantine writing laws for Christians to follow. It focuses on him stopping persecution and making Christianity official. The text doesn't describe new rules, just changes in religious status and treatment.

rewritten.A: You got it! The story says Paul "had helped Christianity spread to many places" before he died. That was the main thing his work did.

This directly describes the main result of Paul's missionary work. The word 'but' signals that despite his death, his spreading work succeeded.
original.B: Incorrect. Paul was a religious teacher and Roman citizen, not a political leader. The passage never suggests he held government positions. It focuses on his religious teaching and traveling, not political power. Keep track of each person's role in the text.

original.D: Incorrect. The passage shows persecution continued long after Paul died: 'For many years, Roman emperors treated Christians as enemies.' Persecution only ended about 300 years later with Constantine. Track the timeline carefully to see when events occurred.

rewritten.A: You got it! The story shows Christianity started small but kept growing even when "Roman emperors treated Christians as enemies." It survived hard times and won in the end.
rewritten.B: Good try! But Christianity grew everywhere in the Roman Empire, even where people worshipped Roman gods. The story shows Christians and Romans had different beliefs in the same places.

rewritten.D: Nice thinking, but Christianity started with Jesus and his teachings, not because emperors wanted it. The story shows emperors actually fought against Christians for a long time.

original.A: Correct! The passage traces how Christianity began small, faced persecution when 'Roman emperors treated Christians as enemies,' but Christians 'did not give up their faith,' and eventually Christianity 'became the official religion.' The entire text develops this theme of persistence through opposition. This is the main thread connecting all sections.
original.B: Incorrect. The passage explains Christianity grew throughout the Roman Empire where people worshipped Roman gods. The conflict between the religions is a key point—Christians grew despite, not in the absence of, Roman religious practices. Reread how Christianity spread in Roman territories.
original.C: Incorrect. The passage states Constantine became emperor 'about three hundred years after Jesus was born,' showing the process took centuries, not one hundred years. The text emphasizes gradual growth over a long period. Pay attention to the timeframe provided.
original.D: Incorrect. The passage clearly shows Christianity started with Jesus's teachings, not because emperors wanted it. In fact, emperors opposed Christianity for most of this history. This contradicts the main narrative of the text.

rewritten.A: Great job! The story says "many Christians" were in the empire by Constantine's time. This shows Christianity grew bigger and bigger over 300 years.
rewritten.B: Good try! This tells us when Jesus was born, but it doesn't show how Christianity slowly grew. Look for details about Christianity getting bigger over time.
rewritten.C: Not quite! Paul being killed shows Christians were still being hurt, not that more people were accepting them. The story asks about growing acceptance.
rewritten.D: Nice thinking, but this just tells us what Christians believed in. It doesn't show that more and more people started accepting Christianity over time.

original.D: Three warriors did volunteer, but the requirement wasn't specifically for three people. The consul asked 'Which of you' (any number) will fight while the bridge is destroyed. The essential requirement was that someone delay the enemy, not that exactly three warriors do so. This confuses what happened with what was required.

rewritten.A: Good try! The army marching to the river happens before the Romans meet to talk about the danger. The story shows Romans learning about danger first, then deciding what to do next.
rewritten.B: You got it! After Romans learn they're in danger, the consul asks "Which of you will stand and fight?" This happens right before Horatius volunteers to help.
rewritten.C: Nice thinking, but Horatius gives his speech after the consul asks for help, not before. The consul asks "Which of you will stand and fight?" first, then Horatius answers.
rewritten.D: Not quite! The Romans start breaking the bridge after Horatius volunteers to fight, not right after learning about danger. They need fighters first to protect the workers.

original.A: The enemy marching to the river happens in paragraph 1, before the meeting where Romans learn of the danger. This event is part of how the danger arises, not what happens after Romans learn about it. The question asks what comes after they learn of danger, and the next logical step is the consul's call for action.
original.B: Correct! The sequence is: I. Romans learn of danger (meeting held), II. Consul asks for volunteers ('Which of you will stand and fight'), III. Horatius and two men fight (after volunteering), IV. Bridge collapses (during the fight). This ordering shows the logical development from problem recognition, to calling for defenders, to actual defense, to resolution. When organizing story structure, identify the key turning point between recognizing the problem and taking action.
original.C: Horatius's speech happens after the consul asks for volunteers - it's his response to that request. The question asks what comes immediately after learning of danger in the conflict development, and the consul's question comes before any individual's response. This confuses the order of problem → call for help → response.
original.D: Tearing down the bridge begins after Horatius volunteers and goes to fight, not immediately after learning of danger. The sequence is: recognize danger → consul asks for fighters → volunteers respond → bridge destruction begins while fighting happens. This skips the crucial step of the consul's call for volunteers.

rewritten.A: Good try! The prayer happens before Horatius jumps into the river, not after. The outline needs what happens between jumping and getting rewards.
rewritten.B: Nice thinking, but fighting the current is part of swimming, not what happens next. The story shows he "made it across" safely to Rome.

rewritten.D: Not quite! His two helpers get to safety much earlier in the story. This outline is about what Horatius does after he jumps alone.

original.A: The prayer happens before Horatius jumps, not between jumping and receiving honors. The question asks what completes the sequence after the jump but before the rewards, and the prayer doesn't fit this position. Review the order: prayer → jump → swim/survival → arrival → honors.
original.B: Fighting the current is part of the swimming action, not a separate event in the outline. The question asks for the key event between jumping and being honored, which is the successful completion of the swim (arriving safely), not the struggle during it. This is a detail within the swimming, not the outcome.
original.C: Correct! The outline shows resolution: I. Action taken (jumps), II. Successful outcome (swims across and reaches Rome), III. Recognition (honored). The text states 'he fought against the current and finally made it across the river to Rome' - this successful arrival is the essential event between the jump and the rewards. When organizing resolution events, identify the successful completion of the challenge before the reward/recognition phase.
original.D: His companions reaching safety happens much earlier (paragraph 4, before Horatius jumps). This doesn't fit in the resolution sequence after Horatius's jump. The question asks about events in the story's resolution phase, and this event belongs to the bridge destruction phase instead.

rewritten.A: Good try! The bridge falling makes Horatius need to escape, but it doesn't show how he gets away. The story tells us what he actually does to cross the river.
rewritten.B: Nice thinking, but beating Astur happens during the fight, not when Horatius escapes. The question asks how he gets across the river after the bridge falls down.

rewritten.D: Not quite! Facing angry soldiers shows the danger Horatius is in, but not how he gets away. The story tells us what brave thing he does to escape.

original.A: The bridge falling traps Horatius and creates the need to escape, but isn't how he escapes. The question asks about how he escapes, and the bridge collapsing is what necessitates the escape, not the method. In summarizing, distinguish between the problem and the solution.
original.B: Defeating Astur is part of the battle, not the escape. This happens before Horatius is trapped and needs to escape. The question specifically asks about how he escapes (crosses the river), not how he fights. When summarizing specific events, focus on actions that directly accomplish the stated goal.
original.C: Correct! For a summary of how Horatius escapes, the essential detail is his method of escape - jumping into the river and swimming across despite the weight of his armor. This action directly answers 'how he escapes' from being trapped between the collapsed bridge and enemy army. Paragraphs 4-5 build to this as the key escape action. When summarizing a specific event, identify the action that directly accomplishes the goal stated.
original.D: Facing angry soldiers describes his situation/predicament, not how he escapes from it. The question asks about the escape method, and being surrounded is the problem, not the solution. To summarize how someone escapes, focus on their action, not the danger they're escaping from.

rewritten.A: Great job! You found that Horatius "held back the enemy" while others chopped down the bridge. He blocked the bridge to save Rome!
rewritten.B: Good try! The story says Romans were "chopping down the bridge," not building one. Horatius blocked the bridge while others broke it down.
rewritten.C: Nice thinking, but the consul was the leader who asked for help. Horatius answered by blocking the bridge while others chopped it down.
rewritten.D: Not quite! The story doesn't say Horatius caught anyone. He "held back the enemy" at the bridge while others broke it down.

original.A: You successfully identified key details by noticing that Horatius stood to stop the enemy while the other Romans destroyed the bridge. The text supports this: “While the other Romans began chopping down the bridge with axes and hammers, these three warriors went out to face the entire Etruscan army by themselves.” Next time, look for clue words like “while” to track who is doing what at the same time in the story.
original.B: You may have mixed up “built” with what really happened. The text says “the other Romans began chopping down the bridge” while Horatius and two men “held back the enemy,” and later the people built a statue—so he blocked the bridge while others broke it, not built a new one. Next time, reread and ask, “Who is doing the action here?” to make sure your answer matches the passage.
original.C: You may have thought Horatius was the leader because he spoke up and asked for helpers, but the text says “The consul spoke to all the people,” and it shows Horatius and two men blocking the bridge while others chopped it down. So the correct answer is that he blocked the bridge while others broke it. Next time, check who is speaking and who is doing the action, and make sure your answer matches the text.
original.D: You may have mixed up who did what; the story never says Horatius caught King Tarquin or his son. Instead, it says, “We will hold back the enemy… Hew down the bridge,” and “While the other Romans began chopping down the bridge, these three warriors went out to face the entire Etruscan army,” showing he blocked the bridge while others broke it. Next time, reread the lines that tell what the hero actually did and pick the answer that matches those exact words.

rewritten.A: You got it! The story says his armor 'made it very hard to swim' to show how tough crossing the river was. This helps us understand what an amazing thing Horatius did!
rewritten.B: Good try! The story mentions the river is deep and fast, but that's not the main reason. It's really about showing how hard it was for Horatius to swim across.

original.A: Correct! The text explicitly states the armor 'made it very hard to swim' and he 'almost drowned in the deep, fast-moving water,' emphasizing the extreme difficulty of his accomplishment. The author includes this near-death detail to help readers understand the magnitude of the challenge Horatius overcame. This detail supports the central message about extraordinary courage by showing what Horatius survived. When analyzing why authors include specific details, consider how they emphasize the significance of the character's achievement.
original.B: While the text mentions the river is 'deep' and 'fast-moving,' the author's purpose isn't to provide information about ancient rivers generally. The detail about almost drowning emphasizes Horatius's specific challenge and courage, not river characteristics. This misidentifies the author's purpose as informational rather than highlighting the hero's achievement.
original.C: While Horatius did pray to the river god, the text emphasizes his own fighting against the current ('he fought against the current'). The 'almost drowned' detail shows the difficulty he overcame, not proof he needed supernatural help. The author's purpose is to emphasize human courage and effort, not religious intervention.
original.D: The text doesn't compare swimming with and without armor - it only describes his specific situation. The author's purpose in mentioning he almost drowned isn't to make comparisons but to emphasize how incredibly difficult and dangerous his escape was, highlighting his courage and determination.

rewritten.A: Good try! Horatius didn't work hard to earn his rewards - he got them for risking his life to save others. The story shows how helping people brings honor.
rewritten.B: You got it! When Horatius risked everything "for his family" and his city, Rome gave him lasting honors. The story teaches that helping others brings respect.
rewritten.C: Nice thinking, but the statue isn't about how to remember history. It shows how grateful Rome was that Horatius saved them by risking his life.
rewritten.D: Close! Horatius wasn't rewarded just for winning a battle. He got honors because he was willing to die to save others from danger.

original.A: The story doesn't emphasize hard work or earning rewards through effort. Horatius receives honors because he risked his life for others, not because he worked to earn them. The lesson is about self-sacrifice for the community, not about working to earn rewards. This misses the core moral about selfless courage.
original.B: Correct! The story's central lesson is revealed through the rewards: when someone risks everything to protect others, the community responds with lasting gratitude and respect (farm for life, permanent statue). The text states the statue told 'how valiantly he had defended the bridge' - the rewards commemorate his self-sacrifice. The story teaches that putting others' safety above your own life creates enduring honor. When determining a story's moral, look at what values lead to positive outcomes and recognition.
original.C: While a statue is mentioned, the story's lesson isn't about monument-building techniques or historical preservation methods. The statue represents gratitude and honor, not a lesson about how to remember history. This focuses on a detail (statue) rather than the moral about self-sacrifice being honored.
original.D: The lesson isn't simply that soldiers should get paid for fighting. Horatius is honored specifically because he volunteered to face impossible odds to save others, not just for winning a battle. The story emphasizes his willingness to die for others ('Death comes to all men... How can a man die better'), not military success. This misses the moral about selfless sacrifice.

rewritten.A: Great job! Horatius "stepped forward" when no one else would help save Rome. He chose to risk his life for his city.
rewritten.B: Good try! The consul asked for volunteers, but didn't order anyone. Horatius chose to help on his own.

original.A: Correct! The story emphasizes Horatius's heroism through his voluntary self-sacrifice: he steps forward when asked 'Which of you will stand and fight' and declares 'How can a man die better than facing terrible danger for his fathers' memory.' His heroism lies in willingly choosing to risk certain death to save others. The text shows his decision to volunteer, his speech about noble death, and facing impossible odds (three against thousands). When identifying why someone is a hero, look for voluntary sacrifice and putting others' safety above personal survival.
original.B: The consul asked for volunteers; he didn't order Horatius specifically. Horatius's heroism comes from volunteering, not following orders. The text emphasizes his choice to step forward: 'Then a brave Roman soldier named Horatius stepped forward.' Following orders shows obedience, but the story's focus is on voluntary self-sacrifice as the heroic quality.
original.C: While Horatius wins battles, the story doesn't establish him as the most skilled fighter. He gets wounded by Astur and nearly drowns swimming - the heroism isn't about superior skills but about willingness to sacrifice himself. The text emphasizes his courage and volunteer spirit ('Who will stand beside me'), not fighting superiority.
original.D: Surviving the river shows his determination, but this happens after his heroic choice. The story establishes his heroism when he volunteers in paragraph 3, before any swimming. His heroism is about choosing to face death for others, not about surviving afterward. The survival is a result of his heroism, not the cause of it.

rewritten.A: Good try! The story talks about breaking the bridge, but it's really about how brave Horatius was. Romans told this story to teach kids about being courageous.
rewritten.B: You got it! Horatius said "Death comes to all men" and chose to risk his life to save everyone in Rome. This story teaches that one brave person can save a whole city.

rewritten.D: Not quite! The story mentions weapons but doesn't teach about fighting. It's really about how "one man" can be brave enough to protect everyone else.

original.A: While bridge destruction is mentioned, the legend focuses on Horatius's personal courage, not military strategies. The statue inscription emphasizes 'how valiantly he had defended the bridge,' not bridge-destruction tactics. Romans preserved this story to teach about heroic values, not engineering or military planning techniques.
original.B: Correct! The legend emphasizes how one man's willingness to sacrifice himself ('Death comes to all men... How can a man die better') saved the entire city. The detailed description of his speech, his battles, his near-death, and the lasting honors all emphasize that individual courage matters enormously. Romans told this story across generations to teach that one person choosing bravery can make the difference between a nation's survival or destruction. When analyzing why cultures preserve legends, consider what values they teach future generations.
original.C: The story doesn't explain Rome's rise to power or focus on defeating Etruscans generally. It focuses narrowly on one bridge, one day, and one hero's actions. The legend teaches about personal courage and sacrifice, not historical explanations of Roman military success or power development.
original.D: While weapons are mentioned, the story doesn't provide detailed technical information about combat. The focus is on Horatius's courage, decisions, and sacrifice - the values he demonstrated - not on documenting ancient warfare methods. This misidentifies the legend's purpose as informational rather than moral/inspirational.

Next time, reread who is being compared and look for clue words like “Like the sun” to match the exact detail.
original.B: You may have thought both the sun and light bulbs use electricity, but the passage explains electricity powers light bulbs (and can go off in storms), while the sun’s light comes from hot gases—not electricity. It also says, “The sun gives off what is called white light,” and “Like the sun, most light bulbs give off white light,” which is why the correct answer is that they both give off white light. Next time, reread the lines that compare the two things and pick the choice that matches what the text says about both.
original.C: You may have mixed up a fact about light with a fact about the sun and light bulbs: the text says, “Light travels at 186,000 miles every second,” not that the sun or light bulbs travel that fast. It also says, “Like the sun, most light bulbs give off white light,” which is the thing they share. Next time, reread who the sentence is about and look for clue words like “Like the sun…” to find what both items have in common.
original.D: You successfully identified key details by noticing the similarity between the sun and light bulbs. The text says, “The sun gives off what is called white light” and “Like the sun, most light bulbs give off white light.” Remember to look for repeated ideas and comparison words like “like” and “both” to answer questions like this.

rewritten.A: Good try! The story says spinning takes "one day" but orbiting takes "365 days." These are very different amounts of time!
rewritten.B: You got it! The story shows spinning makes "day and night" happen daily, while orbiting makes seasons change yearly.
rewritten.C: Nice thinking, but the movements don't cause Earth to get energy from the sun. They create day/night and seasons instead!
rewritten.D: Not quite! Both movements create temperature patterns, but neither makes Earth hotter or colder overall.

original.A: Incorrect. The text clearly states different timeframes: rotation takes one day while orbiting takes 365 days (one year). These movements operate on very different time scales. Review the specific time periods mentioned in Section 3.
original.B: Correct! Section 3 explains that rotation (spinning) happens once every day and creates day/night, while Section 4 explains that the orbit combined with tilt creates seasons over the course of a year. This answer synthesizes information from both sections to show the different time scales and effects.
original.C: Incorrect. While Earth does receive solar energy, this isn't about the two types of movement. The movements (rotation and orbit) create patterns of day/night and seasons - they don't cause energy reception itself. Review what each movement actually produces.
original.D: Incorrect. Neither movement makes Earth inherently hotter or colder overall. Rotation creates day/night cycles in temperature, and tilt creates seasonal temperature variations, but both are about patterns and distributions, not overall temperature changes.

rewritten.A: Good try! These facts don't work together to explain opposite seasons. The story talks about how long Earth takes to go around the sun and how hot the sun is, but that doesn't tell us why some places have winter while others have summer.
rewritten.B: You got it! The story says Earth is "tilted on its axis" and tilted parts get different amounts of sunlight. When one part tilts toward the sun (summer), the other part tilts away (winter)!
rewritten.C: Nice thinking, but these facts don't connect to explain seasons. The story tells us what the sun is made of and that Earth spins, but that doesn't explain why different places have opposite seasons at the same time.
rewritten.D: Not quite! This talks about the sun "rises in the east" and sets in the west each day. But the story says this explains day and night, not why some places have summer while others have winter.

original.A: Incorrect. While both facts are from the text, they don't work together to explain opposite seasons. The orbital period tells us how long a year is, and the sun's temperature explains its energy, but neither explains why opposite seasons occur simultaneously.
original.B: Correct! Section 4 explains that Earth's tilt causes 'one part of Earth is tilted toward the sun' receiving more direct sunlight (summer), while 'the part of Earth tilted away from the sun, there is less sunlight' (winter). These two details work together to show why opposite seasons happen at the same time.
original.C: Incorrect. These facts come from different sections and don't connect to explain seasons. The sun's composition explains its energy output, and the axis explains rotation, but together they don't explain why different parts have opposite seasons simultaneously.
original.D: Incorrect. This describes the sun's apparent daily movement across the sky from Section 2, which relates to day and night, not to why opposite parts of Earth experience opposite seasons at the same time.

rewritten.A: Great job! You found the right answer about "Earth rotates once every day." This spinning is what makes day and night happen.
rewritten.B: Good try! The sun does give light and heat, but that's not why we have day and night. The story says Earth spins once every day to make day and night.
rewritten.C: Nice thinking, but Earth being tilted makes seasons, not day and night. The story tells us "Earth rotates once every day" to make day and night happen.
rewritten.D: Not quite! The story says "now we know" the sun doesn't move around Earth. It's actually Earth that spins once every day to make day and night.

original.A: You successfully identified a key detail by finding the sentence that tells how often Earth spins. The text supports this when it says, “Earth rotates once every day.” Remember to scan for time words and numbers (like “once” and “every day”) to answer “how often” questions.
original.B: You may have focused on a true detail from the first paragraph (“The sun gives us energy… light and heat”), but the question is about Earth’s daily movement. In the section about Earth’s motions, the text says, “Earth rotates once every day,” which causes day and night, so “Earth spins on its axis once every day” is correct. Strategy: Reread the question and match it to the sentence in the passage that directly answers it.
original.C: You may have focused on a seasons detail instead of a daily one. The text says, “Earth rotates once every day” and “It is this spinning that makes day and night,” while being “tilted toward the sun” happens only at certain times of the year to make seasons. So the correct answer is “Earth spins on its axis once every day” because it tells what Earth does each day. Strategy: Look for clue words like “every day” versus “certain times of the year” to match the question.
original.D: You may have focused on how it looks—like the sun moves—but the text says, “Long ago, people believed… But now we know… The sun does not move around Earth,” so that choice is wrong. It also says, “Earth…spins on its axis…Earth rotates once every day,” and this spin makes day and night, which is the correct answer. Next time, look for clue words like “but now we know” and reread that part to be sure your answer matches the facts in the passage.

rewritten.A: Great job! The text says 'like an invisible line' to help you picture something you can't see. This makes it easier to understand how Earth spins.
rewritten.B: Not quite! Scientists know for sure how Earth moves. The word 'invisible' just means you can't see the axis, not that scientists aren't sure about it.
rewritten.C: Good try, but the invisible line actually makes Earth's movement easier to understand! The author uses simple words to help readers picture how Earth spins.
rewritten.D: Nice thinking, but the invisible axis isn't about old beliefs. The story talks about people long ago in a different part than the axis explanation.

original.A: Correct! The text uses this comparison because an axis isn't a physical object you can see - it's a conceptual tool. By calling it 'invisible' and using 'like,' the author helps readers visualize the imaginary line Earth spins around, making the abstract concept of rotation easier to understand.
original.B: Incorrect. Scientists are certain about Earth's rotation and axis. The word 'invisible' doesn't suggest uncertainty - it describes the axis as a conceptual tool, not a physical object. The text presents this as established scientific fact, not as speculation.
original.C: Incorrect. The text uses this language to make Earth's movement easier to understand, not harder. Describing the axis as invisible helps clarify the concept by acknowledging it's imaginary while still being useful for understanding rotation.
original.D: Incorrect. The invisible axis doesn't relate to historical misconceptions. Section 2 addresses why people believed the sun moved around Earth (based on what they observed), but the axis explanation in Section 3 is about helping modern readers understand rotation.

rewritten.A: Good try! This is what made people think the old way - they saw the sun rise and set. The story says this supported the wrong idea, not the right one.
rewritten.B: Great job! The story says "Earth moves around the sun" and that Earth is one of eight planets circling the sun. This shows the old belief was wrong.
rewritten.C: Nice thinking, but the sun being made of hot gases doesn't tell us which moves around which. This is about what the sun is, not about movement.
rewritten.D: Not quite! The sun's hot temperature tells us about the sun itself. But it doesn't show us whether Earth or the sun moves around the other.

original.A: Incorrect. This observation actually supported the old belief - people thought the sun moved around Earth because they saw it rise and set. This is what people used to believe, not the evidence that challenged it. Review what changed people's understanding.
original.B: Correct! Section 2 states 'now we know that this is not what really happens. The sun does not move around Earth. It is Earth that moves around the sun!' The text then explains that Earth is one of eight planets orbiting the sun, providing evidence for the correct model of the solar system.
original.C: Incorrect. The sun's composition and how it produces energy (from Section 1) doesn't address whether Earth or the sun moves around the other. This fact doesn't challenge the old belief about relative motion.
original.D: Incorrect. The sun's constant temperature (from Section 1) tells us about its properties but doesn't provide evidence about which object orbits which. This doesn't address the motion relationship between Earth and sun.

rewritten.A: Great job! The story explains how Earth's spinning makes "day and night" and its tilt makes seasons. You found both Earth movements that create patterns we see!
rewritten.B: Good try! Earth going around the sun helps make seasons, but not day and night. The story says Earth's spinning makes day and night happen.
rewritten.C: Not quite! The story doesn't talk about Earth's hot core making patterns. It says Earth's spinning creates day and night, not heat from inside Earth.
rewritten.D: Nice thinking, but the story doesn't say distance makes these patterns. It explains that Earth's spinning and tilting create the day-night and season patterns we experience.

original.A: Correct! This synthesizes information from Sections 3 and 4: Section 3 explains that rotation (spinning) creates day/night as different parts face the sun, while Section 4 explains that the tilted axis causes parts to receive different sunlight amounts, creating seasons. Both movements produce the patterns we experience.
original.B: Incorrect. While Earth's orbit is important for the yearly cycle, the orbit alone doesn't create day and night - that's caused by rotation (spinning). You need to distinguish between Earth's two different types of movement described in the text.
original.C: Incorrect. The text never mentions Earth's hot core as creating patterns. Day and night come from Earth's rotation (Section 3), and seasons come from Earth's tilt (Section 4), not from heat sources creating these patterns directly.
original.D: Incorrect. Distance from the sun isn't presented as the cause of either pattern. The text clearly states rotation creates day/night and tilt creates seasons - both are about Earth's orientation and movement, not distance. Review Sections 3 and 4 carefully.

rewritten.A: Exactly! The passage says the sun is "in the center" and gives Earth energy. This makes the sun the most important because everything depends on it.
rewritten.B: Good try! The story does tell us about the Latin word, but that's just about the name. The real reason everything relates to the sun is much more important.
rewritten.C: Not quite! The story never talks about how fast the sun moves. It says the sun stays "in the center" while planets move around it.
rewritten.D: Nice thinking, but the story only says the sun is made of hot gases. It doesn't say planets are made of the same stuff as the sun.

original.A: Correct! This conclusion synthesizes multiple ideas: the sun is central ('in the center'), planets orbit around it, the word 'solar' means sun, and Section 1 established the sun provides essential energy. Together, these support the conclusion that the sun's central position and energy make it the most important object.
original.B: Incorrect. While the text explains the Latin origin of 'solar,' this is just an etymological fact about the naming, not a conclusion about why everything relates to the sun. The statement is about the sun's importance, not just word origins.
original.C: Incorrect. The text never discusses the sun's movement speed or compares speeds of different objects. It states the sun is at the center while planets orbit around it - this is about position and relationship, not velocity.
original.D: Incorrect. The text says the sun is made of very hot gases but never states that planets are made of the same materials. In fact, Earth is described as having different properties than the sun. This conclusion isn't supported by the text.

rewritten.A: Great job! You found the big change in the story. The text says "Long ago, people believed" the sun moved around Earth, but "now we know" Earth moves around the sun!
rewritten.B: Good try! The story doesn't talk about Earth spinning faster than people thought. It says people learned that "Earth moves around the sun" instead of the other way around.
rewritten.C: Nice thinking, but the story doesn't say people changed their minds about how hot the sun is. It says people learned "Earth moves around the sun" instead of the sun moving around Earth.
rewritten.D: Close! The story does mention the sun is made of gas, but that's not what people learned over time. They learned "Earth moves around the sun" instead of the other way around.

original.A: Great job! You successfully identified key details by noticing the change from an old belief to what we know now. The text supports this: “Long ago, people believed that the sun moved around Earth… But now we know… It is Earth that moves around the sun!” Next time, look for clue words that show a change (like “but” and “now”) and reread those sentences to confirm your answer.
original.B: You may have mixed up Earth’s spinning with what people learned, but the passage says, “The sun does not move around Earth. It is Earth that moves around the sun!” and only mentions that Earth “rotates once every day,” not that it spins faster. The correct idea is that people learned Earth goes around the sun. Next time, reread to find the exact sentence in the text that answers the question and avoid adding ideas that weren’t stated.
original.C: You may have focused on the detail about the sun’s heat, but the passage doesn’t say people changed their minds about how hot the sun is. It says, “Long ago, people believed that the sun moved around Earth… But now we know… It is Earth that moves around the sun!”, so the right answer is that Earth goes around the sun. Next time, reread the question and find the sentence in the text that answers it before choosing.
original.D: You may have focused on a detail about what the sun is made of, but the passage says, “Long ago, people believed that the sun moved around Earth… But now we know… It is Earth that moves around the sun!”—showing what people learned. So the correct idea is that people learned Earth goes around the sun, not that the sun is gas. Next time, reread and look for clue words like “long ago” and “now we know” to find the big idea the question is asking about.

rewritten.A: Good try! Earth spins around like a top, but it doesn't spin toward the sun. The story tells us spinning makes day and night happen.
rewritten.B: Great job! The story says "As Earth rotates, different parts of it face the sun." Earth's spinning makes day and night for us!
rewritten.C: Nice thinking, but spinning and going around the sun are different things! The story says Earth's spinning makes day and night happen.
rewritten.D: Not quite! The sun does seem to rise in the east, but that's not what the story focuses on. It talks about how spinning creates day and night.

original.A: Incorrect. Earth doesn't rotate toward the sun - it rotates on its axis while orbiting the sun. Also, the sun's brightness at noon isn't the main effect of rotation that the text emphasizes. Review Section 3's explanation of rotation's primary effect.
original.B: Correct! Section 3 clearly establishes this cause-effect relationship: 'It is this spinning that makes day and night on Earth. As Earth rotates, different parts of it face the sun. When the part where you live faces the sun, it gets sunlight. Then it is daytime.' Rotation directly causes the day-night alternation.
original.C: Incorrect. You're confusing rotation with orbit. Earth rotating (spinning) creates day and night, while orbiting (moving around the sun) combined with tilt creates seasons. Review the distinction between these two movements in Section 3.
original.D: Incorrect. While the sun does appear to rise in the east, this isn't framed as a cause-effect relationship with rotation. The text explains this was an observation that led to the old belief. The actual effect of rotation described in the text is the creation of day and night.

rewritten.A: Good try! The text talks about the year-long movement first, then the daily spinning. It doesn't say rotation is different from orbiting.
rewritten.B: Nice thinking, but the text only talks about Earth's movements. It doesn't compare Earth to other planets in this part.
rewritten.C: You got it! The text says "365 days" for orbiting first, then talks about spinning "once every day." It shows the long movement, then the short one.
rewritten.D: Not quite! The text shows these movements do different things, not the same things. One makes years, the other makes day and night.

original.A: Incorrect. Section 3 actually presents the movements in reverse order: it discusses the year-long orbit before the daily rotation. Also, the text doesn't explicitly compare them as 'different from' each other - it introduces each one separately with its own timeframe.
original.B: Incorrect. Section 3 focuses only on Earth's movements and doesn't compare them to other planets' movements. The text mentions eight planets in Section 2, but Section 3's structure is about sequencing Earth's two movements, not comparing across planets.
original.C: Correct! Section 3 states 'It takes about 365 days for Earth to orbit the sun. That is one year! Earth also moves by spinning on its axis' and 'Earth rotates once every day.' The author structures this by presenting the longer timeframe first (365 days), then the shorter one (daily), helping readers grasp the scale difference.
original.D: Incorrect. The text doesn't claim both movements cause the same effects - it distinguishes them: orbit relates to the yearly cycle while rotation creates day and night. The structure separates these movements by their different effects, not by suggesting they produce the same results.

rewritten.A: Good try! The sun giving energy helps plants grow, but that doesn't explain seasons. The story talks about how Earth tilts to make seasons happen.
rewritten.B: Great job! The story says Earth "rotates on its axis" first, then explains how it tilts. You need to know about the axis to understand seasons!
rewritten.C: Not quite! What people believed long ago doesn't connect to seasons. The story explains seasons happen because Earth tilts, not because of old ideas.
rewritten.D: Nice thinking, but the sun being hot doesn't explain seasons. The story says seasons happen because of how Earth tilts, not how hot the sun is.

original.A: Incorrect. While the sun's energy is essential for life (Section 1), this doesn't connect to Section 4's explanation of seasons. Seasons are about how Earth's tilt affects where sunlight hits, not about the sun producing energy in the first place.
original.B: Correct! Section 4 begins by stating 'When Earth rotates on its axis, it is tilted' - directly connecting to Section 3's introduction of the axis concept. The axis must first be understood (from Section 3) before readers can grasp that Earth is tilted on that axis, which creates seasons.
original.C: Incorrect. The historical belief from Section 2 is about whether Earth or the sun moves around the other. This doesn't connect to Section 4's explanation of seasons, which is about Earth's tilt, not about historical misconceptions.
original.D: Incorrect. The sun's temperature and composition (from Section 1) explain how it produces energy but don't connect to why seasons occur. Section 4's explanation focuses on Earth's orientation and tilt, not the sun's properties.

rewritten.A: You got it! The story says "the sun rose in the east" and "set in the west." People thought the sun was moving because that's what they saw every day.
rewritten.B: Good try! The story doesn't talk about measuring temperature when explaining why people were wrong. It's about what people saw the sun doing each day.
rewritten.C: Not quite! The story doesn't say people thought Earth was the only planet. It explains that people were confused about what moves around what.
rewritten.D: Nice thinking, but the story doesn't mention what the sun is made of in this part. It's about people watching the sun rise and set every day.

original.A: Correct! Section 2 explains: 'Each morning, the sun rose in the east. At the end of the day, the sun set in the west. To explain this change, people said the sun moved around Earth.' People reasoned from what they observed - the sun's apparent motion - without realizing Earth's rotation creates this appearance. Their senses led to the wrong conclusion about relative motion.
original.B: Incorrect. Temperature measurement isn't mentioned in Section 2's discussion of the historical belief, and the sun's temperature doesn't relate to whether Earth or the sun moves around the other. The misconception was about relative motion, not temperature.
original.C: Incorrect. Section 2 doesn't suggest people believed Earth was the only planet. The issue was about what moved around what - whether the sun circled Earth or Earth circled the sun - not about how many planets existed.
original.D: Incorrect. The sun's composition (gases versus rock) isn't mentioned in Section 2's explanation of the historical belief. The misconception was about the motion they observed (rising and setting), not about what the sun was made of.
